Award.AwardTitle: Optimized and Modular Architectures for Grid Integration of a Cluster of Hydrokinetic Energy Resources

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Research Objectives and Approaches:

The objective of this research is to advance hydrokinetic energy generation by developing methods to increase the power density and minimize the installation and maintenance costs of the generator, power conditioning system, and interface to the utility grid. The approach is to (i) establish the fundamental tradeoff between cost and power delivered of several alternative hydro-generation systems, (ii) explore alternative machine/converter architectures that reduce the installation and maintenance cost/power delivered, and (iii) develop modular, scalable, and efficient power conditioning and interface systems with high power quality.

Intellectual Merits: This project develops a generalized modular and scalable power conversion structure for further expansion and grid integration of hydrokinetic energy resources. It also establishes a rigorous derivation of the design tradeoffs between several competing technologies that will allow the community to make informed decisions on the architecture that is best suited for a given environment.

Broader Impact: The developed technology will help to increase the large-scale installation of hydrokinetic energy conversion systems and will contribute to the growth of the renewable energy sector. The results and outcomes of the proposed research will provide useful design guidance to reduce the cost of grid integration of hydrokinetic energy resources. The educational program will help to educate and equip the next generation of power engineers with the knowledge and skills required to address tomorrow?s energy challenges. This will contribute to local and national green businesses and industries.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Integration of renewable energy systems into the world’s utility markets has the potential to help address the increasing demand for energy while reducing environmental impact. Hydrokinetic energy of rivers, streams, tidal currents, and other human-made waterways has been strongly recognized as a valuable renewable energy resource. In general, marine and tidal currents are slow moving relative to wind. However, as water density is approximately 900 times that of air, the generated power available from slow flowing water is comparable with that of high speed wind. In addition, while solar and wind are valuable renewable energy resources, neither are as predictable as tidal currents and water streams. While there has been great worldwide interest in grid integration of hydrokinetic energy, a lack of knowledge of the design tradeoffs between competing technologies, the relatively significant installation and maintenance cost, and a general lack of mature components has so far prevented its widespread use. Advancing hydrokinetic energy generation and promoting its further installation requires methods to increase the power density and minimize the installation and maintenance costs of the generator, power conditioning system, and interface to the utility grid. This project aimed at advancing this technology by (i) establishing a rigorous derivation of the design tradeoffs between several competing technologies that will allow the community to make informed decisions on the architecture that is best suited for a given environment, (ii) exploring alternative machine/converter architectures that greatly improve the installation and maintenance cost/power delivered, (iii) developing modular, scalable, and efficient power conditioning and interfacing systems with high power quality that facilitates grid integration of a cluster of hydrokinetic energy generation units, and (iii) developing control methodologies to ensure the integrity of operation of a cluster of generation units.

In this project, a set of component models including generators and power conditioning interfaces that represent all of the electromechanical and power electronic subsystems in a hydrokinetic energy conversion system were modeled. Based on the developed models, we were able to devise appropriate control strategies and create geometries of the optimized generators, filters, and modular and scalable power conditioning architectures. 

The results and outcomes of the proposed research will provide useful design guidance to reduce the cost of grid integration of hydrokinetic energy resources as well as other types of distributed energy resources. Considering that very little work has been performed on this topic by the research community in the U.S., as a part of this effort, we established a partnership with Kohler Corporation. Furthermore, two Ph.D. students finished their studies under this grant.

On the educational front, the results of this work were partially integrated into a graduate course on grid integration of renewable energy resources at Purdue University and power electronics at Georgia Tech.

 

 


Last Modified: 10/21/2016
Modified by: Maryam Saeedifard
